hints_html:
Remember that the average number of points should be

\[\begin{aligned} 0 p(X = 0) + 1 p(X=1) + 3 p(X=3) + 5 p(X=5) + 7p(X=7) + 10p(X=10), \end{aligned}\]

where \(X\) is a random variable representing the number of points. Find the probabilities that X is equal to each value, and compute the sum.

We can find the probability that \(X\) is equal to a given value by looking at all of the different combinations of rolls that can give a value for \(X\). For example:

\[\begin{aligned} p(X=1) &= p(\text{pig 1 lands on its side and pig 2 lands on its feet}) \\ & + p(\text{pig 2 lands on its side and pig 1 lands on its feet})\\ p(X=1) &= \left(\frac{3}{8}\right) \left( \frac{4}{8} \right) + \left( \frac{3}{8} \right) \left( \frac{4}{8} \right) = \frac{24}{64}.\end{aligned}\]

Now, perform the same calculation for the other possible values of \(X\).
hints_latex:
We can find the probability that $X$ is equal to a given value by
looking at all of the different combinations of rolls that can give a
value for $X$. For example:

\begin{align*}
p(X=1) &= p(\text{pig 1 lands on its side and pig 2 lands on its feet}) \\ & + p(\text{pig 2 lands on its side and pig 1 lands on its feet})\\
p(X=1) &= \left(\frac{3}{8}\right) \left( \frac{4}{8} \right) + \left( \frac{3}{8} \right) \left( \frac{4}{8} \right) = \frac{24}{64}.
\end{align*}

Now, perform the same calculation for the other possible values of $X$.
hints_raw:
Remember that the average number of points should be

:<math> 
\begin{align}
0 p(X = 0) + 1 p(X=1) + 3 p(X=3) + 5 p(X=5) + 7p(X=7) + 10p(X=10), 
\end{align}
</math>

where <math> X </math> is a random variable representing the number of points.  Find the probabilities that X is equal to each value, and compute the sum.
We can find the probability that <math> X </math> is equal to a given value by looking at all of the different combinations of rolls that can give a value for <math> X </math>.  For example:

:<math>
\begin{align}
p(X=1) &= p(\text{pig 1 lands on its side and pig 2 lands on its feet}) \\ & + p(\text{pig 2 lands on its side and pig 1 lands on its feet})\\
p(X=1) &= \left(\frac{3}{8}\right) \left( \frac{4}{8} \right) + \left( \frac{3}{8} \right) \left( \frac{4}{8} \right) = \frac{24}{64}.
\end{align}
</math>

Now, perform the same calculation for the other possible values of <math> X </math>.
question: 2 (e)
sols_html:
This game has 9 outcomes, but due to symmetry only 6 of them are distinct. The probabilities are distributed as follows (multiples of 1/64)

[c]@llll@ & pig 1 side & pig 1 feet & pig 1 snout

pig 2 side & 4 \(\times\) 4 & 4 \(\times\) 3 & 4 \(\times\) 1
pig 2 feet & 3 \(\times\) 4 & 3 \(\times\) 3 & 3 \(\times\) 1
pig 2 snout & 1 \(\times\) 4 & 1 \(\times\) 3 & 1 \(\times\) 1

Let X be the random variable that returns the score. Then

\[\begin{aligned} p(X = 0) &= \frac{16}{64} & p(X = 1) &= 2\frac{12}{64} & p(X = 5) &= 2\frac{4}{64} \\ p(X = 3) &= \frac{9}{64} & p(X = 7) &= 2\frac{3}{64} & p(X = 10) &= \frac{1}{64}\end{aligned}\]

and thus the average \(\mu\) is found to be

\[\begin{aligned} \mu &= 0p(X=0) + 1p(X=1) + 3p(X = 3) + 5p(X = 5) + 7p(X=7) + 10p(X = 10) \\ &= 2\frac{12}{64} + 3\frac{9}{64} + 10 \frac{4}{64} + 14\frac{3}{64} +10\frac{1}{64}\quad =\frac{143}{64} \approx 2.23\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
This game has 9 outcomes, but due to symmetry only 6 of them are distinct. The probabilities are distributed as follows (multiples of 1/64)

{| class="wikitable"
|- 
! style=""| 
!scope="col"| pig 1 side
!scope="col"| pig 1 feet
!scope="col"| pig 1 snout
|- border="0"
|style=""| '''pig 2 side'''
|align="center"| 4 &times; 4
|align="center"| 4 &times; 3
|align="center"| 4 &times; 1
|-
|style=""| '''pig 2 feet'''
|align="center"| 3 &times; 4
|align="center"| 3 &times; 3
|align="center"| 3 &times; 1 
|-
|style=""| '''pig 2 snout'''
|align="center"| 1 &times; 4
|align="center"| 1 &times; 3
|align="center"| 1 &times; 1
|-
|}

Let ''X'' be the random variable that returns the score. Then

:<math>
\begin{align}
p(X = 0) &= \frac{16}{64} &
p(X = 1) &= 2\frac{12}{64} &
p(X = 5) &= 2\frac{4}{64} \\
p(X = 3) &= \frac{9}{64} &
p(X = 7) &= 2\frac{3}{64} &
p(X = 10) &= \frac{1}{64}
\end{align}
</math>

and thus the average <math> \mu </math> is found to be

:<math>
\begin{align}
\mu &= 0p(X=0) + 1p(X=1) + 3p(X = 3) + 5p(X = 5) + 7p(X=7) + 10p(X = 10) \\
&= 2\frac{12}{64} + 3\frac{9}{64} + 10 \frac{4}{64} + 14\frac{3}{64} +10\frac{1}{64}\quad  =\frac{143}{64} \approx 2.23
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Short answer question. Show in detail how you arrive at your answer (work will be considered for this problem).

In (a simplified version of) the dice game Pass the Pigs two model pigs serve as dice. Each model pig can either land on the side (with probability p(S) = 4/8), on the feet (with probability p(F) = 3/8), or on the snout (with probability p(N) = 1/8). In each turn both model pigs are rolled. The scoring is as follows:

[c]@llll@ & pig 1 side & pig 1 feet & pig 1 snout

pig 2 side & 0 & 1 & 5
pig 2 feet & 1 & 3 & 7
pig 2 snout & 5 & 7 & 10

Find the average score per turn. You can leave your answer unsimplified as a sum of fractions.
statement_latex:
\textbf{Short answer question. Show in detail how you arrive at your
answer (work will be considered for this problem).}

In (a simplified version of) the dice game
{\emph{Pass the Pigs}}
two model pigs serve as dice. Each model pig can either land on the side
(with probability \emph{p}(\emph{S}) = 4/8), on the feet (with
probability \emph{p}(\emph{F}) = 3/8), or on the snout (with probability
\emph{p}(\emph{N}) = 1/8). In each turn both model pigs are rolled. The
scoring is as follows:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llll@{}}
& pig 1 side & pig 1 feet & pig 1 snout\\

\textbf{pig 2 side} & 0 & 1 & 5\\
\textbf{pig 2 feet} & 1 & 3 & 7\\
\textbf{pig 2 snout} & 5 & 7 & 10\\\\
\end{longtable}

Find the average score per turn. \textbf{You can leave your answer
unsimplified as a sum of fractions.}

(with probability ''p''(''S'') = 4/8), on the feet (with probability ''p''(''F'') = 3/8), or on the snout (with probability ''p''(''N'') = 1/8). In each turn both model pigs are rolled. The scoring is as follows:
